Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Machine Learning for Complex Health Data Analytics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The fields of health and behavioral science are currently undergoing a data revolution. The Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health act of 2009 has resulted in the wide adoption of electronic health records and the emergence of increasingly vast stores of heterogeneous clinical data. Simultaneously, emerging mobile health (mHealth) technologies are enabling the collection of ever-larger volumes of continuous physiological measurements and behavioral self-report data in non-clinical settings. Such data sources have the potential to yield transformative advances in the fundamental understanding of human behavior and health. They also have the potential to significantly enhance numerous applications including data-driven clinical decision support and continuous health monitoring, which will lead to increased efficiency within the healthcare system and facilitate a transition to patient-centered, personalized care. The proposed work will address several fundamental sources of complexity in the analysis of both clinical and mHealth data, enabling researchers in health and behavioral science to extract more useful knowledge from these data sources. The software toolboxes that will be developed will have immediate applications in research conducted by a network of research partners, and will also be broadly disseminated. The integrated education plan includes the development of an innovative applied machine learning course that will provide training in topics like cloud-scale computing that are of direct relevance to massive health data analytics. The outreach plan involves developing and running a health data-themed outreach workshop for underrepresented groups to foster computational thinking and broaden participation in computing.

The ability to learn models from complex data and apply those models to extract useful knowledge is at the core of machine learning research. This proposal seeks to significantly expand the frontiers of machine learning by developing new models and algorithms designed to meet the challenges posed by complex health data analysis. Key sources of complexity in clinical and mHealth data include sparse and irregular sampling, incompleteness, noise, non-stationary temporal dynamics, between-subjects variability, high volume, high velocity and heterogeneity. The presence of one or more of these factors in a given data source is often sufficient to render current machine learning methods ineffective or completely inapplicable. The long-term goal of this research is the development and validation of customized machine learning models and algorithms that can respond to all of these challenges. The objective of this proposal is to develop models and algorithms that address the following specific problems: (1) How can we extract useful knowledge from sparse and irregularly sampled clinical time series data? (2) How can we automate feature discovery from wearable physiological sensor data in the presence of high levels of noise, significant between subjects variability, and heterogeneous sensing modalities? (3) How can we make the learning of physiological time series event detection algorithms robust to event labels that are obtained through self-report mechanisms with limited reliability and temporal fidelity?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction: As individuals interact with healthcare systems, they generate digital traces in the form of electronic health records that reflect their changing state of health through time. Similarly, as individuals use wearable and mobile devices like smart watches, there is an opportunity to collect digital traces that reflect dynamic health-related activities and behaviors. However, these sources of health data can be very complex. Electronic health records only provide a sparse sequence of snapshots of a patient?s state of health with information missing between (and often also within) individual snapshots. Mobile health data from wearables is often also incomplete and mobile sensor data are often noisy.

The overall goal of this research was to develop computational methods (specifically, machine learning models and algorithms) with the ability to make sense of such complex health data despite the significant challenges represented by data sparsity, missing data and noise. In addition to this research objective, this project included an integrated education and community educational outreach plan. This report will detail outcomes in both categories.

Research Outcomes: This research resulted in advances in machine learning algorithms for a collection of problems in both clinical and mobile health data analysis.

Our first line of research on clinical data analysis resulted in fundamental advances in methods for providing decision support based on data that are sparsely and irregularly observed through time. Our work pioneered a collection of approaches for directly analyzing such data. Over the project period, we were able to develop methods with progressively better computational scalability, enabling more accurate analysis of larger data sets. We applied these methods to study the problems of in-hospital mortality prediction and length of stay prediction based on intensive care unit electronic health records data. Other researchers have further extended this work to other clinical data analysis problems including the early detection of sepsis.

Our second line of research included the analysis of mobile health data from wearable sensors and other mobile devices. Here we focused on a collection of key health behavior detection problems including the detection of cigarette smoking from wearable activity and physiological sensors. The key challenges in this domain are noise in the wearable sensor data signals and overall low volumes of data for constructing models. Indeed, data in the mobile health domain are collected though specialized human subjects trials and a key problem is obtaining accurate annotations for events of interest, like individual cigarette puffs in the case of cigarette smoking detection. To this end, we developed models for analyzing such data that leverage structure in semi-periodic activities, like the typical time between cigarette puffs or the typical number of puffs required to smoke a cigarette, to improve detection accuracy. Further, we developed extensions of this approach that are able to robustly learn models even when the time stamps associated with event annotations are noisy, a problem that often occurs for short duration events.  

Education and Outreach Outcomes: The education and outreach plan that was integrated with this work included the development of a senior undergraduate/masters-level applied machine learning course, and the development and offering of an outreach workshop.

The developed machine learning course has a focus on building robust machine learning-based data analysis approaches for use with real-world data. Over the last five years, I have taught the course three times and also developed an open source release of the course material. The developed course has also been taught by four colleagues at my institution. The course is now being offered every semester. Across all offerings at my institution to date, the course has had a total enrollment of over 1,000 students.  

The community educational outreach workshop that this award supported was offered through a partnership with the Girls Inc. Eureka! program. This workshop provided an introduction to programming with MIT Scratch as the programming language. The activities varied from year to year, but focused on using various sensing devices (the Scratch sensor board, smart phones, web cams) to provide input to programs including interactive animations and games created by the participants, who were 8th grade girls from local communities. The workshop was offered for between two and four days each year (depending on scheduling constraints) with three hours of workshop activities per day. In total, more than 75 girls participated in the workshop over the five years of this grant.
